articles.title: About this Workshop
articles.description:
The purpose of this workshop is to introduce the [DemocratizingData.ai](https://democratizingdata.ai/tools/dashboards/) platform and the uses of its dashboard to research-oriented agricultural economists. The DemocratizingData.ai platform has been developed to track data usage statistics for USDA data assets. The goal of the workshop is to gather feedback from invited participants about the current functionality of the USDA dashboard and potential future improvements. The format of the workshop is guided focus groups and interactive discussions designed for attendees to contribute to shaping the ongoing developments of the tool.

The workshop is led by agricultural economists Drs. [Allie Bauman](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=KsJSnW4AAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao), [Alessandro Bonanno](https://agsci.colostate.edu/old-dare/people/faculty/dr-alessandro-bonanno/), [Lauren Chenarides](https://www.linkedin.com/in/laurenchenarides/), and [Rebecca Cleary](https://agsci.colostate.edu/old-dare/people/faculty/dr-rebecca-cleary/) from Colorado State University. The workshop facilitator is Dr. [Mayla Boguslav](https://www.linkedin.com/in/mayla-boguslav-phd-30402239/).

The workshop is supported by funding from the USDA Economic Research Service.

articles.title: Dashboard Demo and Breakout Group Activities
articles.contents:
Contents
Introductions
Activity #1
Thought Experiment
Questions
Quick Poll

Dashboard Walkthrough
Workshop User Guide
Democratizing Data User Guide

Activity #2
Using the Dashboard
Tasks
Reflection Questions


At this point, we kindly ask that you turn on your cameras.
Introductions
Time: 5 minutes
Welcome, everyone! Let’s start off with a quick icebreaker.
Please introduce yourself by sharing:
Your name
The institution or organization you’re affiliated with
Your “sheep score” – Each sheep represents a different mood or feeling. Choose the sheep that best represents how you feel today.
On this sheep-scale, how do you feel today?Activity #1
Total Time: 15 minutes
In today’s rapidly evolving research landscape, the ability to quickly and effectively find relevant datasets can be the difference between publishing in a top field journal or spending months finding the right publication home; securing funding for that highly competitive research grant or not; and spending hours instead of days searching for the right tool for your research project.
We recognize the challenges associated with sorting through vast amounts of available datasets. Initiatives, like DemocratizingData.ai, are being developed to simplify components of this process. These efforts require contributions from the community, which is why we have convened this workshop.
This first activity aims to explore these opportunities by conceptualizing an ideal tool for tracking dataset usage statistics. Understanding these statistics informs the public about the relevance and impact of various datasets, and provides information to researchers about the most widely-used (and under-utilized) resources for their work.
Thought Experiment
To conceptualize this ideal tool, we will engage in a role-playing scenario designed to mimic the decision-making process researchers face when selecting datasets for their studies.
Scenario: Assume that you are new to a certain field of study and you want to do research in this area. You seek out an expert in that field and ask them to suggest datasets you could use to answer your research question. They suggest two datasets you could use. You may only select one.
Objective: We will now walk through a series of questions to understand your decision-making process in determining which, of the two, datasets you would ultimately choose.
Instructions: For answering the questions, we’ll use Idea Boards, an online collaboration tool that allows participants to share their thoughts and insights through sticky notes.
Here’s a quick guide on how to use Idea Boards:
Navigate to the provided link to access our group’s Idea Board.
Once there, you’ll find different columns or sections, each representing a specific question or part of our discussion.
To add your input, click on the ‘Add Note’ button or double-click in the column where you want to post your sticky note.
You can type your thoughts and click ‘Save’ to share them with the group.
Feel free to move your notes around, edit them as the discussion evolves, or ``up vote’’ other sticky notes.
Please navigate to your group’s Idea Board:
Breakout Group
Link to Idea Board
Group 1
Idea Board 1
Group 2
Idea Board 2
Group 3
Idea Board 3
Group 4
Idea Board 4
Questions
What key pieces of information would you need to compare the two datasets?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Pieces of Information” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

What tools exist to help you compare datasets?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Existing Tools” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

What features in a tool exist or would you like to see exist to help you compare datasets?
Add your responses as sticky notes to the “Features” Idea Board.
Time: 3 minutes

Quick Poll


Loading…

Link to poll
Dashboard Walkthrough
Total Time: 7 minutes
Now, we will walk you through a dashboard that provides data usage information about USDA datasets. The primary functions of the dashboard include:
Identifying users of USDA-produced datasets by region, institution, and field
Providing information on publications and citations featuring USDA-produced datasets
Workshop User Guide


The guide above walks through the current version of the Democratizing Data dashboard.
Democratizing Data User Guide


The guide above provides additional information developed by the Democratizing Data team. Link to guide
Activity #2
Total Time: 23 minutes
Now you will explore the utility and functionality of the prototype dashboard on your own. This activity is designed to highlight different aspects of the dashboard and how you can use it to collect data usage statistics.
Using the Dashboard
Time: 15 minutes
Objective: You will use the dashboard to find information about the dataset assigned to your breakout group (see table below). You will be asked a series of questions that are aimed to find specific data usage statistics for your assigned dataset. Answer the specific questions associated with the tasks presented. We will reconvene as a small group to reflect on your experience with the dashboard.
Breakout Group
Assigned Dataset
Group 1
Census of Agriculture
Group 2
FoodAPS
Group 3
Current Population Survey – Food Security Supplement
Group 4
Food Access Research Atlas
Tasks
UPDATE SCENARIOS TO MATCH THE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE SITE
USE CONSISTENT PHRASING TO HAVE THEM ANSWER QUESTIONS WHERE WE KNOW THE RIGHT ANSWERS
HAVE THEM FIND THE “RIGHT ANSWER”
As you navigate the dashboard to answer the questions below, please make use of the chat feature in Zoom to provide comments, in real time, about your experience. Our note takers will be collecting your feedback.
Locate your assigned dataset: Given the USDA-produced dataset have you been assigned, navigate to the location on the page where you can filter through the list of datasets.
Example dataset: Farm to School Census
Identify an expert: Who can we ask for help?
Answer: Becca Jablonski
Identify five papers we can read: What papers can we read?
Answer: Big Hunger
Where is a good place to do a literature review?
Answer: Journal of Hunger and Environmental Nutrition
Where might publish?
Answer:
But, what if I want to target an Ag Econ journal?
Answer: Go to “All Science Journal Classification Subfields”, Select “Economics and Econometrics”
If time allows, clear your filter and pick a new dataset.
Reflection Questions
Time: 8 minutes
After you have gone through the dashboard and answered the questions, let’s review the following questions as a group. Note takers, please document the responses to share with the larger group.
What features of the dashboard did you find particularly useful or surprising?
What limitations or problems did you encounter while navigating the dashboard?
What features would you add to the dashboard?
Thank you for sharing. We will now reconvene with the rest of the participants to share your reflections from these activities.






Go to Large Group Share

            About this Workshop
            Why Are We Here? To introduce the DemocratizingData.ai
            platform, its dashboard, and its uses to researchers in
            agricultural economics.
            What Is It? The DemocratizingData.ai
            platform aims to track data usage statistics for all data
            products produced by the USDA; researchers can access these
            statistics through the dashboard.
            What Is Our Goal Today? To gather
            feedback from invited participants about the current
            functionality of the USDA dashboard and potential future
            improvements.
            How Will We Get There? Attendees of this
            workshop will participate in guided focus groups and
            facilitated discussions, providing inputs that will
            contribute to shaping the development of the tool. We will
            gather your feedback about the current functionality of the
            dashboard and suggestions on potential future
            improvements.

articles.title: Additional Resources
articles.contents:
Discovering Data Use and Value for Research and Policy
Special Issue
This workshop is particularly timely as the Harvard Data Science Review has recently published a special issue, “Democratizing Data: Discovering Data Use for Research and Policy,” presenting cutting-edge ideas on using robust AI tools to support evidence building in public policy and science.




Webinar
An accompanying Webinar (May 21-22, 2024) will feature authors of the papers, providing practical insights and a vision for how bottom-up collaborations and communities of practice can help shape the future of data democratization.

articles.title: Large Group Share
articles.contents:
Reflection Questions
Time: 12 minutes Led by: 
Each note taker, please summarize themes from your group’s discussion:
What features of the dashboard did you find particularly useful or surprising? (Group 1 starts)
What limitations or problems did you encounter while navigating the dashboard? (Group 2 starts)
What features would you add to the dashboard? (Group 3 starts)
Final Question
Time: 8 minutes
Led by: 
Would you use this tool in your own research? Why or why not? (Free talk; Please also make use of the chat feature.)

Go to Concluding Remarks

articles.title: Welcome to Democratizing Data
articles.contents:
Contents
Thank You for Joining Us!
A Special Welcome from Julia Lane
Why Your Participation Matters

Workshop Flow
Breakout Groups


Thank You for Joining Us!
Time: 2 minutes Led by: Lauren Chenarides
We are delighted to have you participate in this workshop, aimed at exploring a prototype dashboard, funded by the USDA, to track data usage statistics for USDA data assets. The USDA and their partners are developing a dashboard to track who and how USDA-produced datasets are used by the public, an initiative inspired by the Foundations for Evidence-Based Policymaking Act of 2018. The purpose of this workshop is to collect feedback from prospective users of the dashboard, and to use these comments to refine and improve the dashboard to better serve the needs of the research community.
A Special Welcome from Julia Lane

Click the image above to watch a welcome video from Julia Lane, one of the creators of the Democratizing Data project.
Why Your Participation Matters
Research Value: Your engagement is central to the development process. As a research-oriented agricultural economist, your insights and feedback will directly influence the development of this platform, ensuring it aligns with the actual needs of the community. Your contributions today will inform the platform’s future enhancements, making it more intuitive and valuable for researchers like you.
Networking and Knowledge Sharing Value: This workshop is designed to be interactive and discussion-based, bringing together research-active agricultural economists. It represents a unique opportunity to connect, share knowledge, and learn from your peers—some of whom you may already know and others you are yet to meet. We hope these interactions foster a sense of community and collaboration.
Community Impact: The exclusivity of this workshop, limited to 40 agricultural economists, highlights the curated nature of this event. Your nomination to participate is a testament to the value we believe you bring to these discussions. Together, we have the potential to shape a tool that will serve not just our immediate needs but also set a benchmark for data discovery and application in policy oriented research.
Workshop Flow
Time: 5 minutes Led by: Allie Bauman
The workshop is being led by a team from Colorado State University. The majority of the workshop will be spent in breakout groups. Each breakout group will have a discussant and a note taker. You will be assigned to a breakout group based on your research area or sub-discipline specialty. Participants will take part in two activities within their breakout rooms. All participants will reconvene to share their experience toward the end of the workshop. The workshop moderator will keep track of time and inform breakout groups how much time remains within the breakout rooms.
Breakout Groups
Time: 3 minutes Led by: Rebecca Cleary
You will now be organized into one of four breakout groups.
Breakout Group
Team Lead
Note Taker
Group 1
Allie Bauman
Brooke Fitzgerald
Group 2
Becky Cleary
Taís de Menezes
Group 3
Alessandro Bonanno
Mackenzie Gill
Group 4
Lauren Chenarides
Sione Ikeme
We value your perspective in shaping the development of a tool. We look forward to your active participation, insightful discussions, and feedback during this workshop.






Go to Breakout Groups
